_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
nkers in bulk form via 3,220-gallon tanker trucks.  The chemical is subdivided into drums and bottles.  Chloroform is then distributed for use in a laboratory setting [subject to Program Level 3].

?    Formaldehyde: Formaldehyde is brought to the facility in tankers in bulk form via 4,400-gallon tanker trucks. The chemical is subdivided into drums and bottles. Formaldehyde is then distributed for use in a laboratory setting [subject to Program Level 3].

?    Hydrofluoric Acid greater than 50%: Hydrofluoric Acid (up to 52%) is brought to the facility in 250-gallon totes.  Each tote contains 2,460-pounds of hydrofluoric acid.  The hydrofluoric acid is subdivided into bottles and then distributed for use in the microelectronic industry [subject to Program Level 3].



FLAMMABLES

?    Ethyl Ether: Ethyl Ether is brought to the facility in tankers in bulk form via 6,700-gallon tanker trucks.  The chemical is distilled and/or subdivided into cycletainers, drums, and bottles.  Ethyl ether is then distributed for use in a laboratory setting [Subject to Program Level 1].



Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the hazards that could potentially be posed to our employees, the public, and the environment if one of these were mishandled or otherwise involved in an accident. 



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention Steps 



We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of chemicals. Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs including: 



?    Process safety information

?    Process hazard analysis 

?    Operating procedures

?    Training

?    Mechanical integrity

?    Management of change

?    Pre-startup review

?    Compliance audits

?    Incident investigation

?    Employee participation

?    Hot work permit

?    Contractor safety



As part of our prevention efforts, we have implemented the following chemical-specific

prevention steps:



?    A process hazard analysis (PHA) on the bulk unloading systems for ethyl ether, chloroform, and formaldehyde following the process from unloading to packaging. In addition we follow the same process for our non-bulk hydrofluoric acid process.

?    Utilize a preventive maintenance program to help ensure proper operation of the systems.

?    Operating procedures are in place and operators trained to make sure all operations are understood and established procedures followed.

?    All changes which do not involve replacement-in-kind are managed through a management of change system to insure proper review prior to implementation.

?    Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted for all systems.

?    Surveillance systems are in place to assist with timely identification and remediation for all leaks at the bulk unloading points.



These individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. Our company and employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we do business. We have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that we are meeting the highest standards for accident prevention.



Five-year Accident History



We keep records of all significant accidental chemical releases that occur at our facility. During the past five years, there have not been any accidental chemical release involving materials covered under the EPA's RMP rule and that resulted in serious injuries, significant property damage, or environmental damage either onsite or offsite.



Emergency Response Program



We maintain a site emergency response plan, which consolidates all of the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  To ensure the effectiveness or our emergency response plan, routine dril

ls are conducted, including testing emergency notice systems.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



The facility completed a process hazard analysis (PHA) which identified several recommendations for enhanced process safety.  These recommendations are summarized in the resulting PHA report and are currently under evaluation.
